Rationale 

The  Project’s  goal  is  to  sustain  the  productivity  of  PNG’s  valuable 
coastal  fisheries  resources  while  reducing  the  poverty  level  of 
coastal  communities  whose  livelihoods  depend  on  fisheries.    The 
Project  will  target  major  fish-landing  areas  and  their  surrounding 
coastal  communities  in  4  of  PNG’s  14  maritime  provinces.  Fishing 
and employment related to fishing is a major source of income and 
sustenance  for  most  households  in  the  target  communities.  The 
Project  has  two  purposes:  (i)  sustain  the  fishing  industry  in  each 
target area with investments to improve the harbor facilities serving 
fishing  vessels,  passenger  boats,  and  local  fish  traders;  and  (ii)

Direct, quantifiable benefits include (i) increased catch value of fish 
and other marine products; (ii) time and cost savings from improved 
fish-landing  access;  and  (iii)  increased  marketing  opportunities  for 
small boat operators, and fish and marine product vendors using the 
harbor  facilities.  Fishers  will  benefit  directly  from  the  improved 
access to the markets, additional fishing time from time savings due 
to improved jetty and road facilities, and increased sales value from 
avoidance of contamination of fish. Nonquantifiable benefits include 
sustaining  the  productivity  of  local  fisheries,  and  improved  health 
and personal safety due to the HIV/AIDS prevention measures and 
provision of toilets and overnight shelters in the harbor areas.   

The beneficiaries include commercial tuna-fishing vessel owners and 
workers,  small-scale  operators,  subsistence  fishers,  and  artisanal 
fishers  engaged  in  production  and  marketing  of  fish  and  marine 
products.  Women  who  constitute  the  majority  of  fish  processors, 
vendors,  and  market  stallholders  will  benefit  directly  from  the 
Project’s  economic  impact  as  well  as  from  improved  health  and 
personal safety measures due to the HIV/AIDS prevention measures 
and  the  improved  sanitation  and  shelters  provided.  The  project 
beneficiaries  will  total  about  150,000  people  (30,000  households) 
from  the  target  coastal  communities  where  poverty  incidence  is 
generally equal to, or above, the incidence of poverty in rural areas, 
41%, which is higher than the national poverty incidence of 37%. 

Projects in PNG face many risks, especially poor transparency and 
accountability  in  public  administration,  which  is  well  documented. 
Political instability and shifting policies also tend to dampen investor 
confidence.  However,  with  respect  to  NFA,  its  new  structure  has 
made  it  much  more  resilient  to  outside  political  pressure  and 
interference.  Another  risk  is  the  issue  of  the  marine  tenure  system, 
which is ill defined. Certain Project activities require collaboration by 
communities  across  traditional  marine  tenure  boundaries,  and  any 
implementation will need prior consultations and written agreement. 
A  major  assumption  is  that  provincial  authorities  and  staff  are 
prepared and willing to see more influence in decision making being 
vested with communities and other stakeholders.

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a 
proposed  loan  to  the  Independent  State  of  Papua  New  Guinea  (PNG)  for  the  Coastal 
Fisheries Management and Development Project. 
 
 

II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND 
OPPORTUNITIES 

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

Commercial fisheries in PNG have performed well in recent years. Exports have 
2. 
grown  significantly  both  in  volume  and  value  (from  1,500  metric  tons  (t)  worth  K13.1 
million  in  1995,  to  48,000  t  worth  K159.7  million  in  2000).1  In  the  past  3  years  license 
and  access  fee  revenues  have  increased  by  a  factor  of  more  than  five,  from  about  K5 
million in 1999 to an estimated K28.3 million in 2001.2  
 
3. 
The  steadily  improving  performance  of  the  sector  can  be  attributed  to  several 
factors. Fishery management policy changes have removed bureaucratic obstacles that 
previously  hampered  the  activities  of  domestic  operators  and  discouraged  foreign 
investors.  Institutional  and  management  improvements  within  the  National  Fisheries 
Authority  (NFA),  which  is  responsible  for  management  of  the  nation’s  fisheries,  have 
made negotiation and collection of fishery access and license fees more efficient. At the 
same time the progressive decline of the kina, relative to other currencies, has increased 
the  international  competitiveness  of  PNG’s  export  fisheries.  As  a  result,  the  size  of  the 
domestic  and  locally  based  fishing  fleets  has  grown  (the  domestic  longline  fleet  has 
grown from 9 to 47 vessels, and about 14 purse seiners are now locally based), onshore 
processing  plants  have  been  established  (a  tuna  cannery  in  Madang  and  a  mackerel 
cannery in Lae, and plans are well-advanced for tuna-loining plants in Lae and Wewak). 
Also  a  wider  range  of  seafoods,  including  value-added  products  such  as  canned  tuna 
and mackerel, are being exported by domestic operators.  
 
4. 
Supply by local commercial fishing operations to PNG’s domestic markets is also 
increasing.  By-catch  from  the  fresh  tuna  longline  industry  is  progressively  supplanting 
imported canned and frozen fish products, which are becoming increasingly expensive in 
kina  terms.  Seafood  imports  were  estimated  to  be  56,000  t  in  1990,  35,539  t  in  1995, 
and 13,473 t in 1998.3 
 
5. 
Most  analysts  predict  that  the  kina  is  unlikely  to  return  to  its  former  high  value. 
The  effect  of  a  weak  kina  increases  the  relative  cost  of  imported  inputs  to  the  fishing 
industry, especially fuel, but also generates greater revenues from export product sales 
given price-elastic export demand, as well as improving product competitiveness on the 
domestic market. Economic conditions thus appear favorable for the continued growth of

6. 
Much  of  the  sector’s  growth  to  date  has  been  assisted  or  mediated  by  ADB’s 
Fisheries Development Project (FDP).4 The FDP commenced in mid-1999 and has led to 
many  of  the  policy  changes  referred  to.  The  FDP  has  also  led  to  institutional 
improvements in NFA, which has become a smaller, more productive, and more focused 
agency  with  a  clear  role  and  mandate,  and  much  better  delivery  capabilities.5    The 
private  fishing  industry,  small-scale  fishers,  resource  owners,  provinces,  and  the 
Government now have greater confidence in NFA. The success and positive impacts of 
the FDP are part of the reason why the present Project, which is a natural follow-on from 
the  FDP,  is  strongly  desired  and  supported  by  the  Government  and  by  the  fishery 
stakeholders. 
 
7. 
In  mid-2000  the  Government  of  PNG  approached  ADB  for  a  loan  to  finance 
initiatives  aimed  at  enhancing  small-scale  fisheries  development  in  rural  areas  of  the 
country.  Loan  fact-finding  took  place  during  26  October–4  November  2001  and  the 
objectives,  scope,  and  cost  estimates  were  agreed  with  the  Government  in  a 
memorandum of understanding signed on 1 November 2001.  
 
B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

1. 

Problems and Opportunities 

Despite  the  encouraging  recent  growth  of  commercial  fishing  activities,  barriers 
8. 
to  continuing  growth  remain.  One  of  the  most  important  is  the  lack  of  infrastructure  to 
enable the efficient transfer of products from areas of resource abundance—which may 
be remote—to local and overseas market outlets. Infrastructure encompasses a range of 
facilities:  wharves,  jetties,  roads,  fuel  depots  and  utilities,  ice-making  machinery, 
refrigeration  plants,  processing  shops  and  factories,  and  transportation,  especially  air 
freight  for  highly  perishable  fresh  and  chilled  seafood  products.  At  present,  only  Port 
Moresby  and  Lae  have  sufficient  wharf  space,  engineering  services,  and  transport 
infrastructure to make them attractive as bases for the commercial fishing fleet. Facilities 
at  both  these  locations  are  now  becoming  overcrowded  and  overstretched  to  the  point 
that future fleet growth is seriously constrained. Expansion of the infrastructure available 
in  these  locations,  and/or  development  of  new  facilities  in  other  locations  is  urgently 
needed. 
 
9. 
Some  of  the  infrastructure  needed  by  the  commercial  fishing  industry  can  and 
should  be  provided  by  the  industry  itself,  or  by  other  parts  of  the  private  sector.  This 
includes  ice  and  refrigeration,  processing  facilities,6  engineering  services,  fuel,  and 
transportation.  In  the  case  of  wharves,  jetties,  roads,  and  utilities,  however,  the  scale

3

and scope of the required interventions are beyond the capacity of the private sector. In 
particular,  the  issue  of  obtaining  land  rights  or  titles  is  extremely  difficult  in  PNG,  as 
almost  all  land  is  owned  by  clans  or  clusters  of  clans  based  on  user  rights;  title  deeds 
often do not exist. In addition, private sector entities that manage to get a land lease for 
a  specific  purpose  run  the  risk  of  “renegotiation”  if  the  landowners  find  the  business 
more  profitable  than  expected  during  the  first  negotiations.  Given  such  constraints, 
public sector intervention is warranted to correct these nonmarket failures.  Standardized 
harbor  charges  are  already  in  place  throughout  PNG  to  cover  operation  and 
maintenance costs (O&M). Wharf or jetty infrastructure owned by NFA is being leased to 
private  sector  operators  with  clear  stipulations  of  obligations,  rights,  and  appropriate 
fees. 
 
Unlike  the  commercial  sector,  PNG’s  artisanal  or  small-scale  fisheries  are  not 
10. 
flourishing. In fact, many are struggling for economic survival. Most artisanal vessels are 
small  and  not  fuel  efficient  (usually  outboard-powered  skiffs  known  as  banana  boats), 
and the increasing cost of fuel (which in kina terms has tripled in the last 3 years) is a 
major burden. In general, small-scale fishers live in poor rural areas where resources are 
relatively  abundant,  but  where  the  local  market  value  of  seafood,  such  as  fruit, 
vegetables,  and  other  garden  produce,  has  not  increased  by  anything  like  the  price  of 
fuel. Rural small-scale producers of these products now find it difficult or impossible to 
cover the cost of transporting their produce to market. The problem is particularly acute 
for  fishing,  which  requires  a  much  greater  input  of  fuel  than  does  marketing  garden 
produce. However, as most rural dwellers are multioccupational, being involved in both 
fishing and gardening, few are unaffected by the increasing cost of fuel. 
 
11. 
Some  small-scale  fishers  catch  products  such  as  lobsters  and  sea  cucumbers, 
the  latter  being  processed  to  beche-de-mer  (dried  sea-cucumber),  to  sell  to  traders  or 
and/or exporters. Because of the declining value of the kina, these products are retaining 
or  increasing  their  value,  and  are  thus  increasingly  being  targeted.  This  has  led  to 
overexploitation  in  some  areas,  particularly  for  sea  cucumbers,  which  are  valuable, 
relatively  easy  to  catch,  and  do  not  require  refrigeration  when  processed.  (The  same 
may apply to trochus and other mother-of-pearl shells, although currently information on 
landings  and  exports  of  these  products  is  insufficient).  The  net  result  is  that  these 
valuable export commodities are now overfished, while the supply of fresh fish and other 
seafood by artisanal fishers to local markets is in decline. 
 
The  solution  to  this  problem  lies  partly  in  providing  small-scale  fishers  with 
12. 
improved  access  to  more  profitable,  export-oriented  markets  for  fresh  fish  and  other 
marine resources. If artisanal fishers could catch high-value products such as sashimi-
grade tuna, deep-water snappers, live lobsters, etc., for the export markets, the value of 
such  products  would  be  many  times  what  it  is  on  local  markets,  and  it  would  again 
become  profitable  for  small-scale  fishers  to  target  such  resources,  which  are  still 
abundant  and  not  overfished.  Even  urban  markets  within  PNG,  such  as  those  in  Port 
Moresby  and  Lae,  pay  far  higher  prices  for  fish  and  seafood  than  can  be  obtained  in 
local markets in rural areas.  
 
13. 
Today, the Government’s policy is to recognize the private sector as the engine 
of  commercial  growth  and  to  provide  it  with  basic  infrastructure,  coupled  with  a  policy 
and regulatory environment in which it can flourish and provide market opportunities to 
rural  producers.  In  line  with  this  approach,  NFA  has  adopted  a  policy  for  the  fishery 
sector of encouraging commercial seafood exporters to purchase products from artisanal 

 

 4 

 

producers.  This  approach  already  works  well  in  the  beche-de-mer,  shell,  barramundi, 
and  Torres  Strait  lobster  fisheries,  and  will  be  extended  to  other  fishery  products.  By 
promoting the development of a wharf and social infrastructure for the fishery sector in 
specific  areas  where  the  conditions  are  most  favorable,  NFA  aims  to  help  the 
commercial  trade  grow  in  those  areas,  thereby  creating  new  market  opportunities  for 
artisanal  fishers.  Lessons  learned  clearly  tell  us  that  the  development  of  small-scale 
fisheries  requires  marketing  links  to  the  growing  commercial  sector,  as  the  highly 
fluctuating artisanal product volumes involved can never justify the cost of building and 
operating infrastructure exclusively for small-scale fishers. This policy is consistent with 
ADB’s country strategy and program update (2002–2004) for PNG. 
 
14. 
Grant funding from the European Union and Australian Agency for International 
Development  is  now  being  channeled  to  programs  for  information  and  training  that  will 
help  small-scale  fishers  understand  market  and  food  safety  requirements,  learn  basic 
business skills, and catch/process the type and quality of products that will best satisfy 
market demand. As of 2002, aid funds7 will also be used to provide loans or finance hire-
purchase schemes that will assist artisanal fishers to acquire larger, more fuel-efficient, 
and  commercially  viable  vessels,  leading  to  a  progressive  improvement  of  small-scale 
fishing operations. However, the introduction of more appropriate vessels into the small-
scale  fishing  fleet  will  be  impeded  unless  there  are  parallel  developments  in  rural 
infrastructure, especially wharves and jetties, which will permit their use. 
 
15. 
On  the  other  hand,  to  prevent  overfishing  and  ensure  that  all  potential  target 
species can be sustainably harvested, appropriate fisheries management plans need to 
be developed. These need to be based on an improved understanding of the capacity of 
specific  resources  to  support  new  or  existing  fisheries,  and  a  clearer  understanding  of 
how  these  resources  respond  to  changes  in  level  of  exploitation.  Better  information  on 
the  degree  to  which  fishery  resources  are  being  exploited  is  also  needed,  based  on  
improved  monitoring  of  fishery  activities  and  harvests.  Resource  management  and 
avoidance of overexploitation are clearly areas where public intervention can be made to 
remedy market failure (A review of the sector is in Supplementary Appendix A.). 
 
16.  Management  of  all  PNG’s  fisheries  is  the  responsibility  of  NFA.  However,  NFA 
recognizes  that  it  has  neither  the  statutory  role  nor  the  comparative  advantage  to 
undertake  extensive  provincial  and  local  interventions.  Larger-scale  commercial  fishery 
management is achieved through liaison between NFA and industry, and by monitoring 
and  policing  a  relatively  small  number  of  vessels  and  businesses.  However  for  small-
scale  fisheries,  involving  thousands  of  participants  dispersed  over  huge  and  often 
remote  areas,  management  is  impossible  without  the  active  participation  of  provincial 
governments, communities, resource users, resource owners, and a wide range of other 
stakeholders  in  the  sector.  Therefore,  NFA  is  keen  to  promote  partnerships  with 
provincial  and  local  governments,  and/or  other  service  providers  that  will  allow  these 
stakeholders to participate more fully in the management process. Recent improvements 
in  NFA’s  organizational  and  financial  arrangements  now  allow  NFA  to  mobilize  its  own 
financial and human resources in support of such initiatives.

issues  is  extremely  limited  outside  of  NFA  and  the  commercial  industry.  For 
management  of  small-scale  fisheries  to  be  possible,  an  effective  consultative  process

19.  Weak  institutions  in  the  fishery  sector  impose  a  disproportionate  burden  on 
women.  The  low  social  status  of  women  in  general,  coupled  with  unsafe  conditions  in 
many  coastal  markets,  where  law  and  order  are  difficult  to  enforce,  make  this  group 
particularly  vulnerable.  It  is  generally  the  responsibility  of  women  to  bring  seafood 
produce to the markets to sell. With profit margins low due to high fuel prices, the added 
time spent in congested and overcrowded landing places make sale of the produce and 
return  home  within  one  day  very  difficult.  Whenever  overnight  stays  are  necessary, 
lodging  expenses  cut  even  further  into  the  already  low  profit,  and  many  women  thus 
choose  to  sleep  wherever  they  can.  In  areas  with  no  facilities  like  public  toilets  or 
meeting places, women face a real risk of being sexually abused when using the beach 
as  a  toilet  after  dark,  or  of  being  sexually  exploited  as  payment  for  “protection”  of 
themselves and their unsold produce while they sleep. Human immunodefficiency virus 
(HIV) and acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) are relatively new  in PNG but 
are  spreading  with  alarming  speed.  So  far  nearly  5,000  people  in  PNG  have  been 
reported  as  having  HIV/AIDS  infection,  but  the  actual  number  is  estimated  to  be  three 
times  higher.  Because  of  high  mobility  and  frequent  overnight  stays  away  from  home, 
fisher groups are among those identified as “high-risk.”  
 
To  assist  in  mitigating  these  conditions,  this  Project  will  construct  necessary

encouraging. The main lessons learned from past projects in PNG can be summarized

project design, (iii) be more flexible regarding project scope, (iv) keep project objectives

Longline Wharf 

40. 
The  proposed  intervention,  which  is  described  in  more  detail  in  Supplementary 
Appendix  C,  is  relatively  small  in  scale  and  cost,  but  promises  to  provide  significant 
returns  and  benefits  for  the  small-scale  fishers  in  their  respective  catchment  areas  as 
well as for larger commercial operators. NFA has introduced the practice of leasing the 
management  of  the  facilities  it  owns  to  the  private  sector.  Such  lease  agreements 
include  obligations  for  public  access,  collection  of    wharfage  fees  to  cover  O&M  costs, 
and general provision of basic services.  
 
41. 
Inputs required for the capital investment are primarily engineering services and 
materials. No special features are included in the proposed wharf component and it will 
be  constructed  within  an  already  developed  harbor  area.  The  proposed  wharf  will  be 
constructed on piles to ensure maximum water exchange and in conformity with already 
proven technology in PNG.  
 
42. 
The  new  tuna  longline  wharf  will  remove  a  constraint  that  is  impeding  the 
development of the commercial tuna longline fleet in Lae. Currently about eight vessels 
are  operating  from  Lae,  and  lack  of  facilities  is  preventing  the  basing  of  additional 
vessels. Expansion of Voco Point wharf facilities will allow up to three longliners to tie up 
alongside  and  unload  their  catch  at  any  one  time,  compared  with  the  present  situation 
when  only  one  vessel  can  tie  up  to  the  fishing  wharf.  Space  requirements  for  turning 
vessels  at  the  adjacent  wharf,  which  is  owned  by  the  Lutheran  Shipping  Service,  will 
necessitate construction of the new wharf as far to the west as possible. This will mean 
that  only  one  side  of  the  wharf  can  be  used  for  longliners,  as  the  water-depth  on  the 
other  side  is  too  shallow.  The  benefits  of  improved  wharf  facilities  are  decreased 
turnaround  times  for  vessels  unloading  fish  and  reprovisioning  with  fuel,  water,  and 
stores,  resulting  in  better  vessel  economy  by  increasing  fishing  days.  In  addition,  the 
current practice of rafting vessels together and having to handle cargo and passengers 
over several vessels will be eliminated. Current practices cause disruption to the efficient 
unloading  and  servicing  of  vessels,  pose  security  risks,  have  safety  and  hygiene 
implications,  and  compromise  the  stringent  food  safety  requirements  for  export-quality 
fish. 
 
43. 
Further growth of the tuna longline export industry in Lae is a key requirement for 
the  provision  of  commercial  market  opportunities  for  small-scale  fishers.  The  growth  to 
present  levels  of  fishing  activity  has  permitted  the  establishment  of  weekly  air-freight 
services  from  Lae  to  Port  Moresby  by  PNG’s  domestic  carrier,  Air  Niugini.  Further 
growth in the fleet will allow the development of additional air-freight capacity, which in 
turn  will  allow  small-scale  fishers  to  access  markets  in  Port  Moresby  or  overseas. 
Several of the existing tuna longline operators in Lae have already expressed interest in 
purchasing  high-value  seafood  products  from  small-scale  fishers  for  resale  in  Port 
Moresby or overseas.

NFA’s  efforts  to  upgrade  hygiene  and  food  safety  standards  for  fish  export.  The  new 
facilities  would  eliminate  this  problem  and  result  in  significant  time-savings  and 
increased  convenience,  in  that  boats  tied  to  the  jetty  will  be  accessible  rather  than 
stranded  on  the  mudflats  or  moored  far  offshore  depending  on  the  state  of  the  tide. 
Other  advantages  include  better  security  for  boats  and  belongings  compared  with  the 
present situation. 
 
46. 
Sanderson Bay is the main harbor in Alotau, the provincial capital of Milne Bay. 
Because of the large number of small vessels in the province, the harbor is congested 
and  overcrowded.  Fishing  vessels  tend  to  receive  lower  priority  than  coastal  trading  or 
passenger vessels and are often forced to moor in the middle of the bay and to load and 
unload in the muddy shore areas at the base of the bay, or to transfer products across 
other  vessels.  The  main  town  market  is  about  1.5  kilometer  from  the  wharf  and  no 
consistent  means  of  transport  exists  between  the  two,  thus  fishers  have  difficulty 
transporting their catch for sale. The suggested structures at Sanderson Bay will provide 
direct  jetty  access  for  the  fishers,  and  the  improved  road  access  will  facilitate  better 
transport to main markets.  
 
47. 
At Voco Point, more than 50 small boats at any time are moored directly onto the 
pebble  beach.  Wave  action  often  damages  hull  and  outboard  engines,  and  makes 
moving produce from the boat to the shore very difficult. The whole area is littered with 
garbage,  and  the  hygienic  situation  in  general  does  not  allow  any  seafood  to  be 
marketed for export. This situation will be alleviated with the construction of a jetty and 
supplementary facilities. 
 
48. 
In  Sanderson  Bay  and  at  Voco  Point,  the  safety  and  sanitation  situation  must 
also be addressed. Very often women traders cannot sell all their produce the same day 
and,  therefore,  have  to  stay  overnight.  No  shelters  are  available  for  rest  areas  or  to 
protect  the  products  for  sale.  The  beach  is  the  only  area  available  for  use  as  a  public 
toilet. For many women traders, this poses a real risk of being accosted at the beach at 
night  or  of  being  forced  to  provide  sex  for  “protection”  of  their  belongings  during  the 

 

 night.  Thus,  the  Project  will  also  construct  sanitation  facilities  and  traditional  transit 
houses or shelters to improve the safety situation during the night, especially for women. 
Given the particular circumstances faced by the small-scale fishers, their income level, 
and the appalling safety and security conditions in general, provision of these facilities is 
merited. 
 
49. 
Other benefits will also arise from these interventions. These include savings in 
time  and  convenience  gained  by  direct  access  from  the  jetty,  reduced  risk  of  personal 
injury  in  getting  on  and  off  vessels,  and  decreased  damage  or  loss  of  goods  being 
transferred. The removal of the need for banana boats to pull up on the beach will also 
result in reduced damage and repair costs from grounding on rocks, etc.

IV. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 

A. 

Benefits 

1. 

General  

65. 
The benefits from the proposed Project are wide ranging, but primarily aimed at 
poorer coastal communities. They include specific benefits that can be directly attributed 
to narrowly defined interventions that can be quantified accurately, such as the improved 
wharf  facility  for  tuna  longliners.  Benefits  associated  with  the  fisheries  management 
support  can  be  roughly  quantified  in  terms  of  saved  present  value  of  the  otherwise 
overexploited  fish  stock,  and  the  diversion  of  effort  into  underutilized  fish  stock.  Other 
hard-to-quantify  benefits  associated  with  the  basic  social  structures  can  only  be 
described in more general and qualitative ways. 
 
66. 
The  Project  will  benefit  rural  coastal  communities.  Approximately  131,000 
households,  which  comprise  23%  of  all  rural  households,  are  engaged  in  fishing  on  a 
regular  basis,  with  about  60%  fishing  for  purely  subsistence  consumption  and  40%  for 
consumption as well as sale. This group will be the primary beneficiaries of the fisheries 
management  support  component.  Beneficiaries  of  the  infrastructure  development 
components  will  be  existing  and  new  small-scale  commercial  and  semicommercial 
fishers,  boat  passengers,  women  fish  traders,  and  commercial  longliners  within  the 
vicinity of Daru, Sanderson Bay, and Voco Point. Appendix 6 provides an assessment of 
the poverty impact. 
 

2. 

Fisheries Management Support 

67. 
The proposed assistance for fisheries management support will ultimately result 
in  a  more  productive  and  sustainable  use  of  coastal  fishery  resources.  Large  benefits 
results  from  investment  in  the  sustainable  use  of  a  renewable  resource  like  fisheries, 
compared  with  the  alternative  of  overexploitation  and  eventual  exhaustion  of  the 
resource.  These  benefits  include  the  attainment  of  a  sustainable  level  of  exploitation, 
and  the  creation  of  a  more  certain  and  favorable  environment  for  the  private  sector  to 
invest in fishing and value-adding enterprises. More certainty about the size of resources 
and  the  level  of  sustainable  catch  for  specific  fisheries  reduces  the  level  of  risk  for 
commercial activities, which otherwise has to be factored into profit expectations.  
 
68. 
The  impact  of  this  component  can  be  best  assessed  by  roughly  estimating  the 
likely  effects  on  the  total  value  of  the  coastal  fishery.  In  2000,  the  total  value  of  the 
outputs  of  coastal  fisheries  was  calculated  to  be  around  K120  million  per  year  ($36 
million) (Supplementary Appendix A). With the effort to halt the overfishing of the stocks 
of  beche-de-mer  and  trochus,  which  combined  account  for  K20  million,  coupled  with 
assistance to direct the coastal fisheries toward underutilized fish stocks, a conservative 
increase  in  the  value  of  production  of  5%,  equivalent  to  an  increase  of  K6  million  per 
year ($1.8 million), can be assumed. This will equate to an incremental economic output 
per  family  of  K46  per  year  (130,000  families  live  in  the  coastal  communities).  The 
improved  management  practices  resulting  from  the  Project  are  expected  to  encourage 

 

  

17

sustainable exploitation and so prevent (or in some cases reverse) the decline of these 
resources.  
 
69. 
Approximately  K1.7  million  will  be  required  to  maintain  the  momentum  of  the 
fisheries management support program after the conclusion of the 5–year development 
period.  With  an  assumed  economic  impact  of  K6  million  per  year,  this  is  a  good 
investment for NFA to fund through its recurrent revenues. 
 

3. 

Longline Wharf 

70. 
Specific  benefits  arising  from  the  capital  investment  include  (i)  incremental  net 
catch  value  from  commercial  and  artisanal  fisheries  sold  for  export  and/or  in  local 
markets; (ii) increased savings in O&M costs and time savings for fisheries and transport 
boat  operators  from  improved  mooring  facilities  and  lower  turnaround  times.  Only  the 
Voco Point longline wharf component was subjected to an economic analysis. Based on 
the benefits noted, the longline wharf has an economic internal rate of return of 24% and 
an  economic  net  present  value  of  K3.192  million  at  12%  economic  opportunity  cost  of 
capital.  The  economic  return  was  tested  for  sensitivity  to  changes  in  the  main 
parameters  of  costs  and  benefits,  and  indicates  that  the  longline  wharf  is  relatively 
insensitive to changes in these factors (Appendix 7 and Supplementary Appendix F). 
 

4. 

Social Infrastructure 

71. 
The  benefits  derived  from  the  development  of  social  infrastructure  at  Daru, 
Sanderson  Bay,  and  Voco  Point  will  be  improved  safety  and  security  for  the  many 
women traders, better movement of fish from sea to shore, better quality produce, and 
more efficient transfer of goods to the marketing chains. In Sanderson Bay, local public 
service vehicles will be able to park in a dedicated area to load fish for transport to the 
market  and  to  consumers  on  the  oil  palm  plantations  nearby,  thereby  improving  the 
transportation link and increasing market opportunities for fishers and fish traders. As a 
result  of  this  development,  coastal  fish  production  marketed  through  Sanderson  Bay 
harbor could increase significantly, perhaps doubling the present low production levels of 
around 500 kilograms per week. 
 
72. 
Additional  benefits  relate  to  improving  the  efficiency  of  the  harbor  by  reducing 
vessel  turnaround  time.  Greater  numbers  of  small  boats  will  be  accommodated  in  a 
more  compact  area,  reducing  the  general  congestion  and    obstruction  caused  by 
anchored vessels and their mooring lines. Time spent waiting for a mooring and having 
to move off moorings to make way for bigger vessels when the harbor is congested will 
also be saved. Dredging of the harbor and removal of the dead coral head in the middle 
will increase the capacity of the harbor and improve traffic flow. 
 
73. 
These  benefits  can  be  quantified,  though  not  valued  due  to  data  constraints,  in 
terms  of  the  opportunity  cost  of  the  time  saved  for  the  passengers  going  about  their 
business bringing their fish and goods to market. Around 170 boats with a total of almost 
2,500  passengers  are  currently  using  the  three  harbors  on  an  average  day.  This 
corresponds to a total time saved of 1,445 hours per day (based on each person saving 
half an hour of his or her daily time in Sanderson Bay and Voco Pint, and 1 hour per day 
in  Daru  where  the  wider  mudflats  pose  a  greater  inconvenience).  On  an  annual  basis, 
the total time saved is estimated at 527,425 hours per year, which on the basis of a 10- 
hour working day is equivalent to 52,743 person-days of time saved per year.

cash  income.  The  typical  household  is  an  extended  family  comprising  on  average  5–7 
members. Those that sell fish or marine products have a division of labor generally along 
gender lines: male members do the fishing, and female members sell what they do not 
consume  to  traders  or  in  the  local  market.  The  cash  income  thus  derived  is  spent  on 
food staples and other basic necessities.  
 
In each target area, the harbor serves as the hub of the local fishing industry so 
79. 
that  fishing  and  fish  trading  by  the  local  population  are  linked  to  the  facilities  and 
marketing  opportunities  emanating  from  the  services  provided  to  fishing  vessels  that 
dock  for  fish  and  supplies.  The  Project’s  investments  to  improve  the  harbor  facilities  in 
each target area will therefore generate a range of direct and spin-off effects related to 
the  increased  value  and  volume  of  fish  and  marine  products  handled  at  each  harbor. 
These are quantified in the economic analyses based on expected income earnings and 
employment  benefits  for  the  many  poor  and  vulnerable  groups  whose  livelihoods  are 
partially or wholly linked to the fishing industry.  
 

2. 

 Gender and Social Issues 

80.  Women are expected to benefit most from improved facilities for retail fish trading 
and  processing  as  they  dominate  this  aspect  of  the  fishing  industry.  Specifically,  the 
small  boat  jetties  and  the  improved  access  to  the  commercial  fish  centers  will  open  a 
market for the fish and other commercially valuable marine products generally caught or 
sold by women traders and vendors. 
 
81. 
Apart  from  the  economic  benefits,  other  nonmonetary  benefits  will  accrue  to 
women  through  the  activities  supported  under  the  community  fisheries  management 
program.  Women  will  be  targeted  for  the  small  business  training  and  technical 
assistance  activities,  encouraged  to  form  stakeholder  associations,  and  motivated  to 
participate in  other community-level activities to be sponsored by the Project. 
 
An  important  issue  is  the  growing  HIV/AIDS  infection  rate  in  PNG,  especially 
82. 
among  women.  The  fishing  industry  is  suspected  to  be  one  of  the  main  sectors  where 
HIV/AIDS  is  transmitted.  The  Project’s  support  for  a  training  and  public  awareness 
program on HIV/AIDS and sexually transmitted diseases will be targeted at women and 
commercial sex workers in the harbor areas.  
 
83. 
A  second  issue  concerns  the  vulnerability  of  women  fish  vendors  to  rape  and 
crime common in the harbor and beach areas. The improved jetties, and construction of 
toilets  and  overnight  shelters  will  greatly  increase  the  personal  safety  of  women  who 
otherwise would have to use unsecured public areas.

Country Risk 

Projects  in  PNG  face  many  risks.  The  poor  transparency  and  accountability  in

The  El  Niño  drought  of  1997;  the  Asian  financial  crisis;  the  continuing  decline  in 
commodity prices for copra, coffee, and cocoa; and the increases in world oil prices in 
2000 and 2001 have resulted in considerable macroeconomic volatility.

difficult.  Most  people  living  in  coastal  communities  in  PNG  have  short-term  needs  and

2. 

Land and Marine Tenure 

92. 
Land disputes continue to bedevil many investment projects in PNG. Traditional 
landowners  continually  interfere  with,  or  sabotage,  the  operations  of  commercial 
enterprises,  public  utilities,  and  even  hospitals  and  schools  in  their  attempts  to  forcibly 
increase royalties, obtain compensation, or otherwise enhance the benefits they receive 
from leases or agreements relating to their land. In some cases, especially in regard to 
mineral exploitation or large-scale industrial projects, provincial or national governments 
may  try  to  accelerate  projects  by  unilaterally  speaking  on  behalf  of  landowners,  which 
invariably leads to disputes later on. In some cases, agreed projects have been blocked 
for months or years because landowning groups cannot agree among themselves about 
how benefits should be distributed. 
 
The  Government  is  trying  to  introduce  land  registration  to  identify  who  or  which 
93. 
groups lay claim to land in different parts of the country. This reform has met with strong 
opposition, and is seen by many as an attempt to alienate traditional owners from their 
land. While this is not the objective of the reforms, the issue has recently been used to 
stir up public opinion against the government of the day. 
 
94. 
For  the  infrastructure  parts  of  the  Project,  ensuring  the  absence  of  land  tenure 
problems as a prerequisite to site selection has minimized the problems relating to land 
tenure.  All  the  infrastructure  interventions  will  take  place  on  land  to  which  the 
Government holds title. While this approach does not entirely guarantee the absence of 
problems, it minimizes their likelihood. 
 
95.  Marine  tenure  presents  its  own  somewhat  different  set  of  problems,  but  these 
can be transformed into opportunities by proper handling. The tenure systems in place 
are  not  defined  adequately  in  the  law  of  the  country,  although  they  are  acknowledged. 
The prerequisites for community-based management include the definition of boundaries 
and the acknowledgement of rights. While the latter is, in theory at least, acknowledged, 
boundaries  have  not  been  formally  established  in  the  marine  zone  and  are  subject  to 
dispute.  The  issue  of  deploying  fish  attracting  devices,  straddling  different  community 
marine tenure claims, will necessitate written agreements from all involved communities 
before deployment. 
 

3. 

Financial Risks 

The  PNG  Government,  as  borrower,  will  onlend  the  funds  to  NFA.  Under  this 
96. 
arrangement,  NFA  will  be  responsible  for  the  provision  of  counterpart  funds  and  for 
financing the debt service on the loan. At the present time, NFA is generating more than 

 

 22 

 

sufficient revenue in access fees, license fees, and fines to meet such an obligation, and 
current projections indicate that this situation will continue. However, several factors may 
act to reduce NFA’s income. These include (i) relocation of foreign fishing efforts further 
east away from the PNG zone; this is expected over the next 1–2 years as a result of the 
strong El Niño phenomenon currently developing; (ii) increasing domestication of PNG’s 
fisheries, which will tend to displace foreign vessels paying access fees; (iii) changes in 
Government policy on fishery access (for instance, granting of access as an adjunct to 
political  or  economic  agreements);  and  (iv)  changes  in  Government  policy  towards 
NFA’s financial autonomy. 
 
97. 
The  major  generalized  financial  risk  is  the  continued  instability  of  the  PNG 
economy, against a background of lowering export revenues, a declining currency, and 
political uncertainty. The continued fall in the value of the kina is of major concern, and is 
having  negative  effects  on  the  buying  power  of  the  bulk  of  the  population.  It  does, 
however,  contribute  to  the  continuing  profitability  of  PNG’s  export-oriented  domestic 
fisheries,  whose  operation  is  central  to  the  Project.  In  addition,  the  declining  kina 
encourages  the  purchase  of  domestic  fish  products  and  a  corresponding  decline  in 
imports. 
 

4. 

Technical Risks  

98. 
PNG  sits  on  the  edge  of  the  “ring  of  fire”  around  the  Pacific  and  is  subject  to 
seismic and volcanic activity. The main technical risks to the Project are geological and 
marine  processes,  including  tsunamis  (tidal  waves),  earthquakes,  surges  and  seiches, 
land  slips  caused  by  seismic  activity,  volcanic  eruptions,  and  sedimentation  from  river 
deposition. The southeast of the country is also subject to cyclones. Designing a project 
for  all  these  possible  natural  disasters  is  impossible.  While  the  infrastructure  plans  are 
compliant  with  design  and  construction  guidelines  and  local  rules  currently  in  force  for 
the Project, a serious natural disaster will present a risk to the Project. 
 
99. 
The project design takes into account the existence of these risks to the greatest 
degree  possible.  Given  the  likelihood  of  the  risks  occurring,  the  benefits  and  positive 
impacts  of  the  Project  are  expected  to  outweigh  the  costs  and  will  bring  significant 
improvement to the quality of life of the rural poor at a time when other options may be 
limited or unavailable.

10. 
The  responsibility  for  future  environmental  management  of  the  proposed  wharf 
and facilities at these three subproject areas will lie with the National Fisheries Authority, 
in  association  with  the  Harbors  Board.  These  entities  represent  government  interest  in 
the facilities, and must ensure that the contractor who builds the facilities addresses and 
incorporates  all  the  required  mitigation  measures  that  have  been  specified  in  this 
document. The proponent should work with the Office of Environment and Conservation 
to implement the monitoring program. 
 
11. 
The monitoring will be done at regular intervals. Specific environmental variables, 
which  may  be  directly  affected  by  construction  and  operation  of  the  wharf  and  beach 
facilities will include in situ analysis undertaken on a quarterly basis for measurement of 
hydrocarbons,  nutrients  (ammonia,  nitrates,  phosphate),  dissolved  oxygen,  salinity  and 
temperature, and suspended particulate matter. 
 
D. 

Conclusions 

12. 
This  initial  environmental  examination  has  determined  that  the  proposed  wharf 
extension and beach facilities at Voco Point in Lae Harbor and Sanderson Bay, as well 
as  the  construction  of  facilities  in  Daru  can  be  constructed  and  operated  with  no 
significant negative environmental impacts. Therefore, no further environmental study or 
environmental impact assessment is required. Subject to the implementation of specified 
mitigation  measures  and  environmental  and  social  benefits  monitoring,  the  Project 
should be able to proceed without any significant negative effects.
